Award.AwardTitle: The Eighth International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC8); Cambridge, Massachusetts; May 1-4, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration: Predictions of effects of natural and human emissions require global atmospheric chemistry models. While such models are available they have not been tested or validated with observations in sufficient detail. This travel support for students, early career and senior experimental scientists will create a forum for modelers to learn from observational experts on how best to evaluate and refine atmospheric chemistry models. It promises to create a community where modelers and experimentalists work synergistically to further the predictive power of atmospheric chemistry. This strategy represents a paradigm shift from the past where the two communities have been working independently. This project will create a meaningful observation-modeling interaction that will enrich the broader atmospheric chemistry community and also showcase and connect research supported by NSF's atmospheric chemistry program. By bringing together senior experimentalists and junior modelers in a targeted manner the meeting will serve to foster scientific training and networking opportunities for the younger scientists, thereby greatly enhancing their career development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided travel support for students, postdoctoral fellows, and keynote speakers to attend and contribute to the 8th International GEOS-Chem meeting held at Harvard University on May 1-4, 2017. GEOS-Chem is a widely used open-source global model of atmospheric chemistry, developed and maintained by an international research community of over 100 institutions.  It has fostered major improvements to our understanding of a wide range of atmospheric issues including air pollution, climate change, and atmospheric deposition effects on ecosystems. Examples of current applications include the causes of extreme air pollution events in China, the role of aerosol particles in mitigating greenhouse warming, and the role of the atmosphere in driving the global transport and deposition of environmental mercury. The travel support provided by NSF greatly enhanced the scope and quality of the information shared at the GEOS-Chem meeting. It enabled far greater participation of young scientists (students and postdocs) than would otherwise have been possible. The participation of these young scientists led to improved plans for development of the GEOS-Chem model moving forward. A new version of the model (GEOS-Chem v11-2) is planned for release in early 2018 that will include many of the priority recommendations  emanating from the meeting.
